results.title: Alice in Wonderland
results.creator_credit: Edward H. Sloman, John W. Considine and Gordon W. Hedwig
results.brief_description: This film opens on a theatre full of people. The conductor steps up and the curtains open - music starts. Irving Berlin music introduces characters from Lewis Carrolls’ “Alice in Wonderland”. As the song plays, Alice encounters each character, each elaborately costumed. Once all the characters have been introduced, the song ends; the curtain closes; the audinece applauds. Devised as a film, this piece plays like a number from a vaudeville show.

results.title: People (Yallourn's Royal Hour 1954; Born to Die; Sir John Monash)
results.brief_description: “Yallourn’s Royal Hour” highlights the visit to Yallourn of Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh on 3rd March 1954. Film of the royal motorcade through Melbourne is shown before their arrival in Yallourn where they inspect the coal extraction site at Yallourn Cut (16 min). “Born to Die” focuses on the prospect that Yallourn will be demolished to enable access to the coal reserves beneath it. Includes comments by the townspeople on their feelings about this. (48 mins) “Sir John Monash” is a tribute to the life of this pioneer Australian. The Vice Chancellor of Monash University speaks on his life and an account of his achievements is given. (27 min)

results.title: Curriculum by Technology
results.creator_credit: Brendan Kenworthy, Bendigo Education Resource Centre, TV Ed Productions and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: Shows how Bendigo Education Resource Centre is introducing new technology into distance education to increase the range of curriculum subjects offered for Year 11 and 12 students in isolated schoolos in the Mallee area: Telepaks, telephone links, fax machines, Macintosh computers, lessons on VHS tapes. Introduction by Justin Shortal.

results.title: The Moka festival
results.creator_credit: J. Campbell Dobbie and Peerless Films
results.brief_description: This film shows the Moka Festival which is held deep in the heart of New Guinea. The many tribes walk great distances carrying with them a live pig lashed to a pole. The pig represents a major feature of the Moka ceremony. Wealthy chiefs distribute their wealth to the less fortunate chiefs and pigs and shells are currency between the villages. The tribal people adorn themselves with paint and feathers and dance at the “festival of giving”. Photography by Arnold M. Maahs.

results.title: Pilkington Brothers offer: the best of both worlds
results.creator_credit: Frank Worth, Cecil Musk and British Information Services
results.brief_description: Two visitors from outer space visit Earth in order to investigate a material unknown on their planet - glass. They are shown the many architectural uses of glass and the many varieties which are available for use.

results.title: The Battle against cancer
results.creator_credit: Swiss Society for Combating Cancer and American Cancer Society
results.brief_description: Prepared for lay audiences this film states that in any typical large group of Americans, one in every eight will die of cancer. To combat the high mortality caused by cancer, early treatment by X-ray, radium or surgery is essential. Microscope-slides are used in this film to show normal cell division and growth, and then the invasion of cancer cells breeding wildly.

results.title: The 1956 Olympic story [Winter Olympics in Cortina, Italy]
results.creator_credit: Norman Mackay, Harry Leaman and Helms Athletic Foundation
results.brief_description: Documentary film on the Olympic Winter Games in Cortina in the Italian Alps, 1956. Sets the panoramic views of Cortina and the venues where the 1956 Winter games will be held whilst highlighting the previous 1952 Oslo Winter games with footage of specific events. Also includes footage of Melbourne in 1956 featuring the Melbourne Cricket Ground and St Kilda Town Hall and images of the 1952 Summer games in Helsinki. Narrated by Fred Hessler.

results.title: Supervising women workers
results.creator_credit: Herbert Kerkow and United States. Office of Education
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Problems in Supervision”.
A factory foreman discusses with the supervisor the “problem” of supervising women workers in his department. The fact is brought out that the same rules apply in supervising both men and women; but, “as women often have not had as much industrial experience as men, and in most cases have more home responsibilities than men, these factors must be taken into account”. Note that this film was made in 1944 and uses such terms as “breaking in” the female workers and “the eternal feminine”. Interesting from a historical point of view.
